segments.text: Now, in terms of tools which you use, is the computer the most important development?
It's not for me.
I mean, I think it is a pretty important development.
No, as far as the, gosh, you know, I don't have that many tools.
I know.
I think the board instrumentation is probably the most important thing as far as it's been added to the oceanographic.
They give us, because the current meter has given us a kind of instrument, a kind of measurement, which is very different from what we had before.
The CTDs and STDs and so forth give us very much more detail about the vertical distribution of properties and the boundaries to go from mass to mass casts.
But it's just better information of the same kind, whereas the current meter really gives
I think that's about the most important thing is that.
Those are not my tools, those are tools that other people have developed.
Besides your own work, although it's very difficult to separate this way, what was the most amazing innovation in oceanography during your period?
What sort of idea struck you?
Oh, that's kind of an interesting question.
I wonder what that answer could be to that.
Something that I could, you know, was really surprised by.
Oh gosh, I don't know.
I suppose, I suppose the, oh I think I know the most, the thing that surprised me the most was the, and it surprised me very early on, was the long distance sound transmission in the so far channel.
I went with Yui and some others down to London, and they had some ships out far away, thousands of miles away, and we had radio in contact with them.
They dropped a charge.
I think they dropped a charge somewhere off Brazil, one block at the end of the South Channel.

We heard for each ship, as they heard the sound go by, and we were sitting there at night, you know, on this radio shack in New London, where the Atlantis would report in, and the Lero or something, I can't remember the names of it, the Jetson and so forth, the different ships would report in, and they just heard the sound going by.
There were long periods in between, of course, 20 minutes or something like that.
The idea that sound could go so slowly, you could hear it, just a small sound at a long distance.
That was really something which was just .
Your future, what do you intend to do next?
Well, I guess I'm going to
I try to play some limited role in this equatorial experiment.
And that's going to be essentially trying to get some long time series measures at the equator from the
a small outfit, a small ship based on a planet like Ocean Island or the Gills.
Think about doing that for the next two or three years.
And I think that's a major thing I'd like to do.
And I think if I can, I'd kind of like to organize a set of density measurements in the center of the subtropical gyro of the Atlantic Ocean.

Using cruises of opportunity, when ships go through and they go across the North Atlantic Ocean to get some systematic station data to look at angular fluctuations and so forth on the central landing gyre.
It's kind of a place which interests me recently.

And I think if I consciously try to figure out how to set up a program like that, then it won't cost very much that ships that are going across back and forth anyway, if I keep aware of their schedules and so forth, somehow I can get 20 or 30 hydrographic stations on each of those cruises that goes across, and maybe divert the line of the cruise a little bit.
Six years projected is a great deal for academicians.
Our minds change so quickly.
Yeah, I know they do, but I think those are the two things that I think could be associated with some useful kind of way.
There were two backup questions I wanted to pick up very quickly that I missed.
What were your parents' occupations?
My father was a chemist.
in several different letter-making concerns in the United States this week and later on.
And my mother was a housewife first, and she was kind of a public relations person, fundraiser for hospitals.
And at the end of her life, she was working mostly trying to raise money for hospitals.
Were you always directed towards the sciences?
Well, I was more influenced by my grandfather, I think.
He was a lawyer, but I had, yeah, I've always wanted to be a lawyer.
I was always a scientist.
Chemistry, science, astronomy, electrical things.
All my high school things.

The afternoons would be, many afternoons would be spent by going down Lower Manhattan and looking at the chemical supply house windows and seeing if they had some Florence flasks that they were selling off in a sale or something, buying for 15 cents or something, right?
There was a canvasser of scientific good stores.
They almost always had St. Martin County.
We had a summer program, Dusty Chemical Company.
Where did you do your undergraduate training?
Yeah, I was doing my undergraduate training.
Well, yeah.
Before that, it was the Freeport High School on Long Island.
Before that, in Townsend Harris, Manhattan.
The Brooklyn Public School, 217.
And never varied all this time from scientific orientation.
Yeah, I always wanted to be a scientist.
I had chemical companies trying to make chemistry sets for kids and sell them for 25 cents, you know, things like that.
Fourth grade.
I was very strong in chemistry for a long time.
I always wanted to go into science.
When I went to Yale, we had some kind of diagnostic achievement test or something.
And after I took those tests, they counseled me.
the basis of those tests, but it was very basically unwise for me to go into science.
And he gave me some good arguments, you see.
I mean, you know, I really am kind of weak on certain kinds of formal, quantitative ways of thinking.
Mathematics doesn't come as easily to me as it does to other people.
Abstract thinking doesn't.
I can see that, and I recognize that very clearly.
But, so he wanted me to go into law, he said.
And, well, gosh, no, I just didn't want to, that was all.
So, I mean, I could see, as the years went on, that it had some serious difficulties, really, to basically,
Basically, certain kinds of things I really can't do very well.
Take all that terrible business in thermodynamics, where you're constantly taking different partial derivatives of things with respect to other things.
And the formal manipulations of thermodynamics
You have some body of gas, which you're squeezing, and heating, and cooling, and pressing, and expanding in constants, and this and constant that, and so forth.
I try to vision.
I'm very sure that the people who are good at that
don't really think in very concrete terms.
I think they think in very formal terms.
And I find myself absolutely unable to depart on an intellectual tour very far, which goes away from some very clear concrete terms.
And so
So I can understand things, simple mechanics and so forth, and do calculations in it.
But when it gets formal or abstract, then it becomes quite difficult for me.

If you look at mechanics, I'm probably wrong about this, but if you look at mechanics, probably the part of mechanics which is formulated most nearly to thermodynamics, for example, in some sense, is the use of Hamiltonians in setting up a mechanical problem.
It just seems so absolutely, it seems so absolutely, crazily abstract to set up a mechanical problem in that formulation.
But I just, I just can't do it.
And I know to other people it's just an alternate means of problem solving which is self-evident and obvious to them as what looked to me like a straightforward way to do it.
So I think, I think those tests were right, you know, really.
But these people really, people really
The motivation sort of counts too, but if you want to do something, you start to move on to do what you want to do, I think.
I maybe could have had quite a lot of fun out of it.
Anything you'd like to add to the table?
Well, I don't think so.
Any advice you'd like to give to young oceanographers?
I don't really think it's possible because the
Things have changed so much over a 30-year period that I wouldn't feel confident to give people advice as to what kind of a satisfactory life that they...
I haven't tried to influence my children, for example, to be interested in science or oceanography.
particularly, I think that it's not at all clear that it would be a nice thing for them to do.
I guess what I would, I guess my only, I wouldn't give advice, but the wish that I would have for people
is that they could find some intellectual area in the world that was pretty much underdeveloped.
And they could, by some lucky chance, find some place like that and develop some structure there.
Now, I don't suppose it is oceanography.
There are probably areas of knowledge and science, and even in oceanography, which are sufficiently undeveloped so that those names aren't on a map yet.
We don't know what those areas are, and if a person is lucky enough to find some kind

knowledge space like that, so he can have the excitement and fun of poking around there first of all by himself, then I should think he could have a fun intellectual experience a little bit similar to the one that I've been able to have.
But, of course,
You can enter into a, it's like, you know, it's like getting into a, in the virgin forest kind of period of things.
It would still be very exciting, I suppose, to, in the highly evolved municipal stage, still find interesting things to do.
But when you have the area of science a little bit all to yourself, and you can sort of ask the first questions, that is kind of fun.
I would recommend that they would have some fun if they can find a place to be a pioneer, and they'd have some fun being a pioneer.
I don't know.
I think it must be partly luck when you find those places.
And certainly places which were pioneering places aren't after a while.
The first pioneers have gone through.
That's right.
They've messed it all up.
No longer virgin timber.
Now it's cut over.
That's right.
It's all messed up.
It's all cut over and built up or something.
That's not advice.
It's just, I guess it's advice.
But it's not advice.
It doesn't give you any indication as to how to implement it, where to look.
But I think there's an opportunity to buy around everywhere.
